did.abstract: Abraham Yates, Jr. (1724-1796) was an American politician and pamphleteer. A radical Whig who was elected to New York provincial congresses and conventions, he was chairman of the convention (1776-1777) which drafted the first state constitution, served as a state senator from 1777 to 1790, and was mayor of Albany from 1790 to 1796. He wrote anti-federalist pamphlets with his relative, jurist Robert Yates (1738-1801), under the pen-name The Rough Hewer. Collection consists of correspondence, writings, speeches, notes, estate papers, photograph, and printed matter. Correspondence, 1754-1825, concerns the activities of Abraham Yates as a political figure in New York State. Writings, notes and speeches include essays he wrote on the U.S. Constitution, notes on proceedings in Congress, speeches to the delegates to Congress in 1786, The Rough Hewer manuscript, and notes for histories of New York and Albany. Also, papers relating to the Manor of Rensselaerwyck and the Albany Committee of Correspondence, land and family records, photograph of painting of Yates, and other items such as broadsides and a legal treatise by Thomas Wentworth printed in London in 1663.

bioghist.p: Abraham Yates, Jr. was born In 1724 at Albany and died there in 1796. He was a radical whig politician who possessed considerable power and influence in northern New York. Related to the jurist Robert Yates he was, like him, an active revolutionary patriot and anti-federalist. As pamphleteers they shared the pen-name, The Rough Hewer. (See Dict. of American Biography, p. 601-602.)

scopecontent.p: The collection consists of correspondence, 1754-1825, of Abraham Yates, Jr., George Clinton, Robert Livingston, Jr., Christopher Yates, Robert Yates, Abraham Lansing, and others, concerning the activities of Abraham Yates Jr. as surveyor, Lawyer, Land speculator, sheriff of Albany political colleague and adversary, pamphleteer, anti-federalist, chairman of the Albany Committee of Correspondence, provincial congressman from Albany, Chairman of the convention that drafted the first New York State constitution, state senator, and mayor of Albany. There also are a letter-book, 1779-1782, relating to his office as commissioner for congressional loans to New York State, essays of Abraham Yates, Jr. on the constitution, speeches to delegates to congress, notes for his histories of New York and Albany, papers relating to the Manor of Rensselaerwyck, and to the Albany Committee of Correspondence, some indentures, mortgages, accounts, legal papers, official documents, broadsides relating to Philip Schuyler as a candidate for Senate, Federaoso and Aaron Burr, and support for Jay and Van Rensselaer, and a photograph of a painting of Abraham Yates Jr. The bulk of the collection was bequeathed to Victor Hugo Paltsits who donated it to the library.
